y: Stepan Arkadyevitch is a Russian writer. He is best known for his novel "The Death and Life of Ivan the Terrible" In the book, he tells of the death of his wife, and how he tried to find a solution.

Levin was almost of the same age as Oblonsky; their intimacy did not rest merely on champagne. They were fond of one another in spite of the difference of their characters and tastes. It seemed to each of them that the life he led himself was the only real life.

Kitty hesitated; she wanted to say further that ever since this change had taken place in her, Stepan Arkadyevitch had become insufferably repulsive to her. “Oh, well, everything presents itself to me, in the coarsest, most loathsome light,” she went on.

“No,” answered Varenka with a smile, laying her hand on the music, “no, let’s have that one.” And she sang it just as quietly, as coolly, and as well as the others. When she had finished, they all thanked her again, and went off to tea.
“So you will send me that book, dear count? I’m very grateful to you,” she said to the young Swede. “That’s our aristocracy, prince!” the Moscow colonel said with ironical intention.

“All I knew was that something had happened that made her dreadfully miserable, and that she begged me never to speak of it.” “I am awfully, awfully sorry for her. You suffer only from pride,” said Darya Alexandrovna.

“Yes, time will pass; time, which arranges all things, and the old relations will be reestablished,” Alexey Alexandrovitch told himself. She is bound to be unhappy, but I am not to blame, and so I cannot be unhappy.”

“Wasn’t it awful?” she said, looking at Anna with eyes that seemed to lay bare all her soul. “Yes; I had no idea it would be so thrilling,” said Anna, blushing.

In the middle of the old man’s account of his acquaintance with Sviazhsky, the gates creaked again, and laborers came into the yard from the fields. The laborers were obviously of the household: two were young men in cotton shirts and caps, the two others were hired laborers in homespun shirts. “What have they been ploughing?�
Levin felt a longing, now that he was so dissatisfied with his own life, to get at that secret in Sviazhsky that gave him such clearness, definiteness, and good courage in life.
Levin tried through her to get a solution of the weighty enigma her husband presented to his mind. But he had not complete freedom of ideas, because he was in an agony of embarrassment.

They crowded round Levin with happy faces, quarreling among themselves, and offering their services. Trying not to offend the other sledge drivers, and promising to drive with them too, Levin took one and told him to drive to the Shtcherbatskys'.
“Well, God help you!” said Betsy. “I think you’re giving way to pessimism. You must rouse yourself, you must look life in the face. But the chief thing was having to settle this.”

“Mother, darling, sweet one!” he shouted, flinging himself on her again and hugging her. “I don’t want that on,’ he said, taking off her hat. And as it were, seeing her afresh without her hat, he fell to kissing her again.” “But what did you think about me?

“Oh, here is he!” she said, glancing at the portrait of Vronsky, and she suddenly recalled that he was the cause of her present misery. “But where is he? How is it he leaves me alone in my misery?’ she thought all at once with a feeling of reproach.

“No, if it were unjust, you could not enjoy these advantages and be satisfied—at least I could not. The great thing for me is to feel that I’m not to blame.” “We shan’t go to sleep, you know. Come, let’s go!” Levin did not answer.

Darya Alexandrovna had to consent, and on the day fixed Levin had ready for his sister-in-law a set of four horses and relays, getting them together from the farm and saddle-horses. “If you don’t want to wound me, you’ll take mine.”

Anna did not even glance at him; but again it seemed to Darya Alexandrovna out of place to enter upon such a long conversation in the carriage. “I don’t think anything,” she said, “but I always loved you, and if one loves anyone, one loves the whole person, just as they are and not as one would like

Kitty asked Levin what he was going to do in the morning. He said he was only going to Katavasov to talk to him about his work. She asked him if he would like to go to the concert with her. Levin said he would certainly go.

Levin sat down in one of the empty chairs that were standing round the table, and in a whisper asked a student sitting near what was being read. Though Levin was not interested in the biography, he could not help listening, and learned some new and interesting facts about the life of the distinguished man of science.

“But how could he go away, leaving me in such a state? How can he live, without making it up with me?” She went to the window and began looking into the street. “Why, then, he has never received it!” she thought.

“You know Count Vronsky, the notorious one... is going by this train?” said the princess with a smile full of triumph and meaning, when he found her again and gave her the letter. “Oh, yes, of course.” While they were talking the crowd streamed by them into the dining-room.
